bioghist.p: William Nathaniel Bradley (1871-1962) was a Philadelphia pediatrician. He graduated from the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy in 1892, and received an M.D. from the University of Pennsylvania in 1894. Bradley taught Histology (from 1894-1896) and pediatrics (from 1910-1912) at Jefferson Medical College. In 1896, he became the chief of the Children's Clinic at the South Eastern Dispensary. In 1909, Bradley was appointed Medical Director of the Starr Center Association. He also worked as assistant physician in the outpatient departments at Pennsylvania Hospital and Philadelphia Orthopaedic Hospital (1909-1911). He served as Pediatrist at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia from 1912 to 1915. From 1915 to 1929, Bradley had charge of the pediatric department at Howard Hospital. He also was instrumental in the establishment of Babies' Hospital of Philadelphia in 1911. From 1912-1926 he taught pediatrics at the School of Medicine of the University of Pennsylvania, and from 1917 to 1946, he worked on the pediatric staff at Philadelphia General Hospital. Bradley also taught at the Graduate School of Medicine of the University of Pennsylvania (1921 to 1946). He served as consulting pediatrist to the Municipal Hospital for Contagious Diseases (1936-1946) and Wills Eye Hospital (1932-1945). Bradley retired from active practice in 1955.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of 17 scrapbooks (some disbound) containing correspondence and reports, 1907-1962. Materials include: correspondence with colleagues about referrals and consultations; letters related to meetings of the Philadelphia Pediatric Society and other professional societies; invitations and programs from meetings; letters regarding papers submitted to [MSSP] section of Pediatrics; acknowledgments of reprints; letters of appointment; and letters of recommendation. Also included are one folder of reprints; correspondence and research material (clippings, notes, reprints) for "Philadelphia physicians in art," 1945-1961, and a scrapbook of portraits of notable physicians (photographs, engravings, clippings); and loose photographs and cabinet cards with portraits of physicians, along with invitations and programs.
